abstract.p: Robert E Roistacher letter says reopening of Staten Island Railroad should be clarion call to reopen Amtrak line along Manhattan's West Side for export of trash from that borough (April 18 article)

block.p: ''City Reopens Old Rail Line for Staten Island Trash and Freight'' (news article, April 18) should be heard as a clarion call to reopen the Amtrak line along Manhattan's West Side for the export of trash from that borough.

''City Reopens Old Rail Line for Staten Island Trash and Freight'' (news article, April 18) should be heard as a clarion call to reopen the Amtrak line along Manhattan's West Side for the export of trash from that borough.

There is no need to inconvenience the residents of the Upper East Side with an expensive and unnecessary marine transfer station, when after the Javits Center's plan to relocate its truck parking area is implemented, a truck-to-rail facility could easily be built between 11th and 12th Avenues bounded by West 33rd and West 34th Streets. Other points along that track also lend themselves to small transfer stations, so the burden can be spread.
The yahoos of Far West Side development can easily incorporate the transfer facility under a platform on which they can build more trash-generating megaprojects, as is their wont.
Robert E. Roistacher Yangshao, China, April 18, 2007
The writer is former chairman of the Manhattan Solid Waste Advisory Board.
